turns.speaker: user
turns.utterance: Hey, I'm thinking of participating in a hackathon this weekend. Any advice on how to prepare? I'm feeling a bit overwhelmed!

turns.speaker: agent
turns.utterance: Sure thing! Preparing for a hackathon can be a lot. First, define your goals. What do you want to achieve? Then, brush up on your skills, especially the ones related to your project idea. Also, research common tech stacks used at hackathons and choose one you're comfortable with. Finally, get a good night's sleep beforehand! Let me know if you have any specific areas you'd like me to elaborate on.

turns.speaker: user
turns.utterance: That's helpful, thanks! I'm leaning towards using React and Node.js. Any recommendations for specific libraries or frameworks that are popular for projects related to web development?

turns.speaker: agent
turns.utterance: Okay, for React and Node.js projects, I recommend looking into libraries like Axios (for making HTTP requests), Redux or Zustand (for state management – though Context API can work too!), and of course, a UI component library like Material UI or Ant Design. For backend, consider using Express.js as your framework. However, picking one is tricky because it depends a lot on your project. What problems is it supposed to solve? Also, how complex will your project be?

turns.speaker: user
turns.utterance: Alright, that gives me a good starting point. One thing I'm struggling with: the hackathon rules state we can't use any code that already exists as-is; everything needs to be original. How do I deal with pre-built libraries like the ones you mentioned, and how do I prove originality of code? I'm really confused now.
